perturbation.original_text: Each party shall defend, indemnify and hold the other party and its Affiliates, and their respective directors, officers, employees, agents, successors, assigns, licensees and distributors harmless from and against any and all judgments, settlements, damages, penalties, costs and expenses (including, but not limited to, reasonable attorneys’ fees) arising out of any third party claims relating to the Indemnifying Party’s breach or alleged breach of any of its representations, warranties, covenants or obligations hereunder. The party seeking indemnification (the “Indemnified Party”) will give prompt notice to the indemnifying party (the “Indemnifying Party”) of any claim for which the Indemnified Party seeks indemnification under this Agreement; provided, however, that failure to give prompt notice will not relieve the Indemnifying Party of any liability hereunder (except to the extent the Indemnifying Party has suffered actual material prejudice by such failure). The Indemnified Party will reasonably cooperate (at the Indemnifying Party’s expense) in the defense of any claim for which the Indemnified Party seeks indemnification under this Section 13. The Indemnified Party shall have the right to employ separate counsel and to participate in (but not control) any such action, but the fees and expenses of such counsel will be at the expense of the Indemnified Party unless: (i) the employment of counsel by the Indemnified Party has been authorized by the Indemnifying Party; (ii) the Indemnified Party has been advised by its counsel in writing that there is a conflict of interest between the Indemnifying Party and the Indemnified Party in the conduct of the defense of the action (in which case the Indemnifying Party will not have the right to direct the defense of the action on behalf of the Indemnified Party); or (iii) the Indemnifying Party has not in fact employed counsel to assume the defense of the action within a reasonable time following receipt of the notice given pursuant to this Section 13, in each of which cases the fees and expenses of such counsel will be at the expense of the Indemnifying Party. The Indemnifying Party

The party seeking indemnification will give notice to the indemnifying party of any claim for which indemnification is sought. perturbation.explanation: The removal of the obligation to 'defend' and the phrase 'hold harmless' significantly reduces the scope of protection for the indemnified party. Removing 'Affiliates, and their respective directors, officers, employees, agents, successors, assigns, licensees and distributors' limits who can claim the protection. Deleting 'any and all judgments, settlements, damages, penalties, costs and expenses (including, but not limited to, reasonable attorneys’ fees)' reduces the coverage to a vaguer "damages and expenses." Furthermore, deleting the detailed provisions regarding the Indemnified Party's right to employ separate counsel and related cost allocation introduce a legal risk. Under New York law, parties have certain implied rights in indemnification contexts, but these are less defined than the original contractual specifications. The changes weaken the indemnitee's position and create ambiguity.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York General Obligations Law § 5-322.1, which outlines specific requirements for indemnification clauses in certain contracts, particularly regarding negligence, may be implicated due to the reduced clarity and scope of the indemnification.

perturbation.original_text: EXCEPT AS EXPRESSLY STATED IN SECTION 12, THE PARTIES HEREBY DISCLAIM ALL WARRANTIES, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, INCLUDING, WITHOUT LIMITATION, ANY IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE, CONCERNING THE SUBJECT MATTER OF THIS AGREEMENT.
perturbation.changed_text: THE PARTIES HEREBY DISCLAIM ALL WARRANTIES, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, CONCERNING THE SUBJECT MATTER OF THIS AGREEMENT.
perturbation.explanation: This alteration omits the specific disclaimer of 'ANY IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.' Under New York law (Uniform Commercial Code § 2-314 and § 2-315), these implied warranties automatically apply to sales of goods unless explicitly disclaimed. By removing the specific language, the contract opens itself up to potential claims that these implied warranties were not effectively disclaimed, increasing legal risk, especially if the 'Titles' provided under the agreement are considered 'goods'.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York Uniform Commercial Code § 2-316 (Exclusion or Modification of Warranties). This section specifies how implied warranties can be excluded or modified and requires specific language for disclaiming merchantability and fitness.

perturbation.original_text: Any dispute, controversy and/or difference which may arise out of or in connection with or in relation to this Agreement, shall be solely and finally settled by binding arbitration pursuant to then-current rules of the International Chamber of Commerce. Such arbitration shall be held in New York, New York. The merits of the dispute shall be resolved in accordance with the laws of the State of New York, without reference to its choice of law rules. The tribunal shall consist of three arbitrators, each of whom shall be knowledgeable in the subject matter hereof. The arbitration shall be conducted in the English language, and all documents shall be submitted in English or be accompanied by a certified English translation. The arbitrators will provide a written explanation to the parties of any arbitration award. The award thereof shall be final and binding upon the parties hereto, and judgment on such award may be entered in any court or tribunal having jurisdiction, and the parties hereby irrevocably waive any objection to the jurisdiction of such courts based on any ground,
perturbation.changed_text: Any dispute arising out of or relating to this Agreement, shall be settled by arbitration in New York. The arbitration shall be conducted in accordance with the laws of the State of New York. The award shall be final and binding.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause specifies arbitration under the International Chamber of Commerce rules, requires three arbitrators knowledgeable in the subject matter, mandates a written explanation of the award, and includes a waiver of objection to jurisdiction. The modified clause omits these specifics. This creates legal risk because the original clause provided a clear framework, while the modified clause is vague. Under New York law, arbitration agreements must be clear and unambiguous. Omitting key procedural details could lead to challenges regarding the enforceability of the arbitration agreement or disputes over the arbitration process itself.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York Civil Practice Law and Rules (CPLR) Article 75, which governs arbitration agreements and proceedings in New York. The reduced specificity could make it harder to enforce the arbitration agreement under CPLR Article 75.
